title: healthequal: Calculating summary measures of inequality
text: Measuring monitoring inequalities health important informing policies programs aim tackle health inequities. Broadly defined, inequalities health measurable differences health across population subgroups defined dimensions inequality (demographic, socioeconomic geographic characteristics). Summary measures inequality summarise amount inequality across subgroups single number – facilitates comparison inequalities time across different settings indicators. Summary measures health inequality use either disaggregated data individual-level data inputs. Disaggregated data refers health indicator data recorded different subgroups population defined according dimensions inequality, demographic, socioeconomic geographic characteristics (wealth quintiles subnational regions). record dataset contains data population subgroup. Individual-level data refers data record dataset contains data pertaining individual.

what: About summary measures of health inequality
title: healthequal: Calculating summary measures of inequality
text: Simple summary measures (difference ratio) compare two population subgroups. can calculated dimensions inequality (two subgroups ). Complex measures calculated inequality dimensions two population subgroups consider situation subgroups. can calculated dimensions two subgroups. Selecting appropriate measures analysing reporting inequality involves considering several methodological issues. considerations relating characteristics underlying data, determines types measures can calculated calculated: Whether dimension inequality ordered non-ordered. Ordered dimensions subgroups inherent ordering (education level wealth quintiles), non-ordered binary dimensions subgroups logically ranked (subnational regions, ethnicity sex). Whether dimension inequality two two subgroups. Simple measures can calculated inequality dimensions, complex measures can calculated dimensions two subgroups. optimum level achieved health indicator. favourable indicators, goal attain maximum level; adverse indicators, goal attain minimum level. Note indicators optimum level. optimum level impacts calculation certain summary measures. also considerations relating properties different measures desired purpose analysis: Whether inequality measured absolute relative terms. Absolute measures indicate magnitude inequality population subgroups, relative measures show proportional inequality subgroups. Whether subgroups weighted according population size . involves value judgement depending purpose analysis. selection reference point non-ordered measures. instance, may mean, best-performing subgroup user-selected reference group. paper Summary measures health inequality: review existing measures application provides information considerations.

title: healthequal: Calculating summary measures of inequality
text: following summary measures health inequality included healthequal library: Difference (d) Ratio (r) Absolute concentration index (aci) Relative concentration index (rci) Slope index inequality (sii) Relative index inequality (rii) -group variance (bgv) -group standard deviation (bgsd) Coefficient variation (covar) Mean difference mean - unweighted weighted (mdmu mdmw) Mean difference best-performing subgroup - unweighted weighted (mdbu mdbw) Mean difference reference subgroup - unweighted weighted (mdru mdrw) Index disparity - unweighted weighted (idisu idisw) Theil index (ti) Mean log deviation (mld) Population attributable risk (parisk) Population attributable fraction (paf)

title: healthequal: Calculating summary measures of inequality
text: Absolute Concentration Index (ACI) summary measure health inequality can used ordered dimensions. information ACI function type following command, display corresponding help file: OrderedSample dataset can used calculate ACI. Two arguments required: est (subgroup estimate, recorded estimate dataset), subgroup_order (order subgroups increasing sequence). arguments, pop (number people within subgroup, recorded population sample dataset) weight (sampling weight survey data), optional. Lastly, force argument can used estimate ACI estimates missing.
code: ?aci with(OrderedSample,      aci(est = estimate,          subgroup_order = subgroup_order,          pop = population          )      ) measure estimate       se  lowerci  upperci 1     aci  4.30052 1.284031 1.783865 6.817174

what: Calculate the slope index of inequality (SII)
title: healthequal: Calculating summary measures of inequality
text: Slope Index Inequality (SII) summary measure health inequality can used ordered dimensions. slope index inequality (SII) absolute measure inequality represents difference estimated indicator values -advantaged -disadvantaged, taking consideration situation subgroups/individuals – using appropriate regression model. information SII function type following command, display corresponding help file: SII can calculated using disaggregated individual data. example, IndividualSample dataset, survey weighted dataset, used. type data, five arguments required: est (individual estimate, recorded sba dataset), subgroup_order (order subgroups increasing sequence), weight (sampling weight), psu (primary sampling unit) strata (variable identifying strata).
code: ?sii with(IndividualSample,      aci(est = sba,          subgroup_order = subgroup_order,          weight = weight,          psu = psu,          strata = strata           )      ) measure   estimate          se    lowerci    upperci 1     aci 0.07801353 0.002950566 0.07223053 0.08379654

title: healthequal: Calculating summary measures of inequality
text: -group variance (BGV) summary measure health inequality can used measure inequality across non-ordered dimensions inequality. calculated weighted average squared differences subgroup estimates weighted mean. Type ?bgv view corresponding help file. NonorderedSample dataset can used calculate BGV, requires two arguments: pop (number people within subgroup, recorded population sample dataset), est (subgroup estimate, recorded estimate dataset). argument se (standard error subgroup estimate) required compute corresponding 95% confidence intervals.
code: with(NonorderedSample,      bgv(pop = population,          est = estimate,          se = se          )      ) measure estimate       se  lowerci  upperci 1     bgv 50.42023 9.560196 31.68259 69.15787

title: World Health Organization (WHO) — IndividualSample
text: Births attended skilled health personnel defined birth attended skilled health personnel divided total number live births women aged 15-49 years occurring period prior survey. Skilled health personnel include doctors, nurses, midwives medically trained personnel, defined according country. DPT3 measured among one-year-olds indicate received three doses combined diphtheria, tetanus toxoid pertussis containing vaccine given year.line definition used Countdown 2030 Collaboration, Demographic Health Surveys (DHS), Multiple Indicator Cluster Surveys (MICS) Reproductive Health Surveys (RHS). Economic status determined using wealth index, based owning selected assets access certain services. wealth index divided five equal subgroups (quintiles) account 20% population. Economic status ordered dimension (meaning subgroups inherent ordering). dataset can used calculate ordered summary measures health inequality, including: absolute concentration index (ACI), relative concentration index (RCI), slope index inequality (SII) relative index inequality (RII).

title: Absolute concentration index (ACI) — aci
text: absolute concentration index (ACI) absolute measure inequality indicates extent indicator concentrated among disadvantaged advantaged subgroups, absolute scale.

title: Absolute concentration index (ACI) — aci
code: aci(   est,   subgroup_order,   pop = NULL,   weight = NULL,   psu = NULL,   strata = NULL,   fpc = NULL,   lmin = NULL,   lmax = NULL,   conf.level = 0.95,   force = FALSE,   ... )

title: Absolute concentration index (ACI) — aci
text: est indicator estimate. Estimates must available subgroups/individuals (unless force=TRUE). subgroup_order order subgroups/individuals increasing sequence. pop number people within subgroup (disaggregated data). Population size must available subgroups. weight Individual sampling weight (required data come survey). psu Primary sampling unit (required data come survey) strata Strata (required data come survey) fpc Finite population correction (data come survey sample size large relative population size). lmin Minimum limit bounded indicators (.e., variables finite upper /lower limit). lmax Maximum limit bounded indicators (.e., variables finite upper /lower limit). conf.level Confidence level interval. Default 0.95 (95%). force TRUE/FALSE statement force calculation missing indicator estimate values. ... arguments passed methods.

title: Absolute concentration index (ACI) — aci
text: estimated ACI value, corresponding estimated standard error, confidence interval data.frame.

title: Absolute concentration index (ACI) — aci
text: ACI can calculated using disaggregated data individual-level data. Subgroups disaggregated data weighted according population share, individuals weighted sample weight case data surveys. calculation ACI based ranking whole population -disadvantaged subgroup (rank 0) -advantaged subgroup (rank 1), inferred ranking size subgroups. ACI can calculated twice covariance health indicator relative rank. Given relationship covariance ordinary least squares regression, ACI can obtained regression transformation health variable interest relative rank. information inequality measure see Schlotheuber, ., & Hosseinpoor, . R. (2022) . Interpretation: larger absolute value ACI, higher level inequality. favourable indicators, positive values indicate concentration indicator among advantaged, negative values indicate concentration indicator among disadvantaged. adverse indicators, reverse: positive values indicate concentration indicator among disadvantaged, negative values indicate concentration indicator among advantaged. ACI zero inequality. Type summary measure: Complex; absolute; weighted Applicability: Ordered; two subgroups Warning: confidence intervals approximate might biased.

title: Absolute concentration index (ACI) — aci
text: Schlotheuber, ., & Hosseinpoor, . R. (2022). Summary measures health inequality: review existing measures application. International Journal Environmental Research Public Health, 19 (6), 3697.

title: Absolute concentration index (ACI) — aci

title: Between-group standard deviation (BGSD) — bgsd

title: Difference (D) — d

title: Difference (D) — d
text: est subgroup estimate. Estimates must available two subgroups compared. se standard error subgroup estimate. missing, confidence intervals D calculated. favourable_indicator Records whether indicator favourable (1) non-favourable (0). Favourable indicators measure desirable health events ultimate goal achieve maximum level (skilled birth attendance). Non-favourable indicators measure undesirable health events ultimate goal achieve minimum level (-five mortality rate). ordered_dimension Records whether dimension ordered (1) (0). subgroup_order order subgroups increasing sequence. Required dimension ordered (ordered_dimension=1). reference_subgroup Identifies reference subgroup value 1. conf.level Confidence level interval. Default 0.95 (95%). ... arguments passed methods.

title: Difference (D) — d
text: estimated D value, corresponding estimated standard error, confidence interval data.frame.

title: Difference (D) — d
text: D calculated : D = y1 - y2, y1 y2 indicate estimates subgroups 1 2. selection two subgroups depends characteristics inequality dimension purpose analysis. addition, direction calculation may depend indicator type (favourable #'  adverse). Ordered dimension: Favourable indicator: -advantaged subgroup - Least-advantaged subgroup Adverse indicator: Least-advantaged subgroup - -advantaged subgroup Non-ordered dimension: reference group & favourable indicator: Highest estimate - Lowest estimate reference group & adverse indicator: Lowest estimate - Highest estimate Reference group & favourable indicator: Reference estimate - Lowest estimate Reference group & adverse indicator: Lowest estimate - Reference estimate Interpretation: Greater absolute values indicate higher levels inequality. D zero inequality. Type summary measure: Simple; relative; unweighted. Applicability: dimension inequality. Warning: confidence intervals approximate might biased.

title: Population attributable fraction (PAF) — paf
text: population attributable fraction (PAF) relative measure inequality shows potential improvement average indicator, relative terms, achieved population subgroups level indicator reference group.

title: Population attributable fraction (PAF) — paf
code: paf(   pop = NULL,   est,   ordered_dimension,   subgroup_order = NULL,   setting_average = NULL,   favourable_indicator,   scaleval,   conf.level = 0.95,   ... )

title: Population attributable fraction (PAF) — paf
text: pop number people within subgroup. Population size must available subgroups. est subgroup estimate. Estimates must available subgroups. ordered_dimension Records whether dimension ordered (1) (0). subgroup_order order subgroups increasing sequence, dimension ordered (ordered dimension=1). setting_average reported setting average. Setting average must unique setting, year, indicator combination. population specified subgroups, setting average used. favourable_indicator Records whether indicator favourable (1) non-favourable (0). Favourable indicators measure desirable health events ultimate goal achieve maximum level (skilled birth attendance). Non-favourable indicators measure undesirable health events ultimate goal achieve minimum level (-five mortality rate). scaleval scale indicator. example, scale indicator measured percentage 100. scale indicator measured rate per 1000 population 1000. conf.level Confidence level interval. Default 0.95 (95%). ... arguments passed methods.

title: Population attributable fraction (PAF) — paf
text: estimated PAF value, corresponding estimated standard error, confidence interval data.frame.

title: Population attributable fraction (PAF) — paf
text: PAF calculated difference estimate reference subgroup setting average, divided setting average multiplied 100. information inequality measure see Schlotheuber, ., & Hosseinpoor, . R. (2022) . indicator favourable PAF < 0, PAF replaced 0. indicator adverse PAF > 0, PAF replaced 0. selection reference subgroup depends characteristics inequality dimension indicator type. -advantaged subgroup ordered dimensions. non-ordered dimensions, subgroup highest estimate favourable indicators subgroup lowest estimate adverse indicators. Interpretation: PAF assumes positive values favourable indicators negative values non-favourable (adverse) indicators. larger absolute value PAF, higher level inequality. PAF zero improvement can achieved (.e., subgroups reached level indicator reference subgroup surpassed level). Type summary measure: Complex; relative; weighted Applicability: Warning: confidence intervals approximate might biased. See Walter S.D. (1978) information standard error formula.

title: Population attributable fraction (PAF) — paf
text: Schlotheuber, ., & Hosseinpoor, . R. (2022). Summary measures health inequality: review existing measures application. International Journal Environmental Research Public Health, 19 (6), 3697. Walter, S. D. (1978). “Calculation Attributable Risks Epidemiological Data.” International Journal Epidemiology 7 (2): 175–82.

title: Ratio (R) — r
text: R calculated : R = y1/y2 y1 y2 indicate estimates subgroups 1 2. selection two subgroups depends characteristics inequality dimension purpose analysis. addition, direction calculation may depend indicator type (favourable adverse). Ordered dimension: Favourable indicator: -advantaged subgroup / Least-advantaged subgroup Adverse indicator: Least-advantaged subgroup / -advantaged subgroup Non-ordered dimension: reference group & favourable indicator: Highest estimate / Lowest estimate reference group & adverse indicator: Lowest estimate / Highest estimate Reference group & favourable indicator: Reference estimate / Lowest estimate Reference group & adverse indicator: Lowest estimate / Reference estimate Interpretation: R assumes positive values. value R one, higher level inequality. R 1 inequality. Type summary measure: Simple; relative; unweighted. Applicability: dimension inequality. Warning: confidence intervals approximate might biased. See Ahn J. et al. (1978) information standard error formula.

title: Relative concentration index (RCI) — rci
text: relative concentration index (RCI) relative measure inequality shows gradient across population subgroups. indicates extent indicator concentrated among disadvantaged advantaged subgroups, relative scale. RCI can calculated using disaggregated data individual-level data. Subgroups disaggregated data weighted according population share, individuals weighted sample weight case data surveys.

title: Relative concentration index (RCI) — rci
code: rci(   est,   subgroup_order,   scaleval = NULL,   pop = NULL,   weight = NULL,   psu = NULL,   strata = NULL,   fpc = NULL,   method = NULL,   lmin = NULL,   lmax = NULL,   conf.level = 0.95,   force = FALSE,   ... )

title: Relative concentration index (RCI) — rci
text: est indicator estimate. Estimates must available subgroups/individuals (unless force=TRUE). subgroup_order order subgroups/individuals increasing sequence. scaleval scale indicator. example, scale indicator measured percentage 100. scale indicator measured rate per 1000 population 1000. pop number people within subgroup (disaggregated data). Population size must available subgroups. weight Individual sampling weight (required data come survey) psu Primary sampling unit (required data come survey) strata Strata (required data come survey) fpc Finite population correction (data come survey sample size large relative population size). method Normalisation method bounded indicators. Options available Wagstaff (wagstaff) Erreygers (erreygers) correction. lmin Minimum limit bounded indicators (.e., variables finite upper /lower limit). lmax Maximum limit bounded indicators (.e., variables finite upper /lower limit). conf.level Confidence level interval. Default 0.95 (95%). force TRUE/FALSE statement force calculation missing indicator estimate values. ... arguments passed methods.

title: Relative concentration index (RCI) — rci
text: estimated RCI value, corresponding estimated standard error, confidence interval data.frame.

title: Relative concentration index (RCI) — rci
text: calculation RCI based ranking whole population -disadvantaged subgroup (rank 0) -advantaged subgroup (rank 1), inferred ranking size subgroups. RCI can calculated twice covariance health indicator relative rank, divided indicator mean. Given relationship covariance ordinary least squares regression, RCI can obtained regression transformation health variable interest relative rank. information inequality measure see Schlotheuber, ., & Hosseinpoor, . R. (2022) . Interpretation: RCI bounded -1 +1 (-100 +100, multiplied 100). larger absolute value RCI, higher level inequality. favourable indicators, positive values indicate concentration indicator among advantaged, negative values indicate concentration indicator among disadvantaged. adverse indicators, reverse: positive values indicate concentration indicator among disadvantaged, negative values indicate concentration indicator among advantaged. RCI zero inequality. Type summary measure: Complex; relative; weighted Applicability: Ordered; two subgroups Warning: confidence intervals approximate might biased.

title: Relative concentration index (RCI) — rci
text: Schlotheuber, ., & Hosseinpoor, . R. (2022). Summary measures health inequality: review existing measures application. International Journal Environmental Research Public Health, 19 (6), 3697. Wagstaff . (2005). bounds concentration index variable interest binary, application immunization inequality. Health Economics, 14:429–432. Erreygers G. (2009). Correcting Concentration Index. Journal Health Economics, 28:504–515.

code: # example code data(IndividualSample) head(IndividualSample) #>   id  psu strata   weight             subgroup subgroup_order sba dtp3 #> 1  1   88      1 0.351672           Quintile 3              3   1   NA #> 2  2 1337     38 0.431545 Quintile 1 (poorest)              1   1    1 #> 3  3  450     18 0.482483           Quintile 2              2   1   NA #> 4  4 1692     56 0.407390 Quintile 1 (poorest)              1   0   NA #> 5  5  752     23 1.547062 Quintile 5 (richest)              5   1   NA #> 6  6 1033     30 2.429523 Quintile 5 (richest)              5   1   NA #>   favourable_indicator indicator_scale #> 1                    1             100 #> 2                    1             100 #> 3                    1             100 #> 4                    1             100 #> 5                    1             100 #> 6                    1             100 with(IndividualSample,      rci(est = sba,          subgroup_order = subgroup_order,          weight = weight,          psu = psu,          strata = strata          )      ) #>   measure   estimate          se    lowerci  upperci #> 1     rci 0.09723792 0.003677656 0.09002985 0.104446

title: Relative index of inequality (RII) — rii
text: relative index inequality (RII) relative measure inequality represents ratio estimated indicator values -advantaged -disadvantaged, taking consideration situation subgroups/individuals – using appropriate regression model. RII can calculated using disaggregated data individual-level data. Subgroups disaggregated data weighted according population share, individuals weighted sample weight case data surveys.

text: est indicator estimate. Population size must available subgroups. scaleval scale indicator. example, scale indicator measured percentage 100. scale indicator measured rate per 1000 population 1000. weight Individual sampling weight (required data come survey) psu Primary sampling unit (required data come survey) fpc Finite population correction (data come survey sample size large relative population size). strata Strata (required data come survey) conf.level Confidence level interval. title: Relative index of inequality (RII) — rii
text: calculate RII, weighted sample whole population ranked -disadvantaged subgroup (rank 0) -advantaged subgroup (rank 1). ranking weighted, accounting proportional distribution population within subgroup. population subgroup considered terms range cumulative population distribution, midpoint range. indicator interest regressed midpoint value using appropriate regression model (e.g., generalized linear model logit link), predicted values indicator calculated two extremes (rank 1 rank 0). ratio estimated values rank 1 rank 0 (covering entire distribution) generates RII value. information inequality measure see Schlotheuber, ., & Hosseinpoor, . R. (2022) . Interpretation: RII value one inequality. RII positive values. Greater absolute values indicate higher levels inequality. value RII one, higher level inequality. favourable indicators, values larger one indicate concentration indicator among advantaged values smaller one indicate concentration indicator among disadvantaged. adverse indicators, values larger one indicate concentration indicator among disadvantaged values smaller one indicate concentration indicator among advantaged. RII multiplicative measure displayed logarithmic scale (values larger one equivalent magnitude reciprocal values smaller one, e.g., value 2 equivalent magnitude value 0.5). Type summary measure: Complex; relative; weighted Applicability: Ordered; two subgroups Warning: confidence intervals approximate might biased.

title: Relative index of inequality (RII) — rii
text: Schlotheuber, ., & Hosseinpoor, . R. (2022). Summary measures health inequality: review existing measures application. International journal environmental research public health, 19 (6), 3697.

title: Theil Index (TI) — ti
text: TI calculated sum products natural logarithm share indicator subgroup, share indicator subgroup population share subgroup. TI may easily interpreted multiplied 1000. information inequality measure see Schlotheuber, ., & Hosseinpoor, . R. (2022) . Interpretation: Greater absolute values indicate higher levels inequality. TI zero inequality. TI sensitive differences setting average (use logarithm). Type summary measure: Complex; relative; weighted Applicability: Non-ordered; two subgroups Warning: confidence intervals approximate might biased. See Ahn J. et al. (2018) information standard error formula.
